newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- MARCH 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- MARCH 7.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--Following indications of compromise by Albanian President Sali Berisha's with the opposition, Dutch Foreign Minister and head of the EU Council of Ministers Hans Van Mierlo heads to Tirana today following talks in Athens and Rome yesterday. Berisha agreed on a 48-hour suspension of military activity and amnesty for all armed citizens to turn in their guns.

--The disappointing tax revenues rate for the first two months of the year has raised doubts about whether budget targets will be met as well as the spectre of new measures to cover the gap. For the moment, the finance ministry is intensifying tax checks on businesses.

--US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright insisted on the need for a Greek-Turkish dialogue as the best way to resolve differences in the Aegean in her meeting with Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos in the US.
--Teachers and parents yesterday criticised Education Minister Gerasimos Arsenis's announcements on how to make up lessons lost over the eight-week teachers' strike as "half measures".
--Rebels in the south of Albania are sceptical about Berisha's promises and unlikely to hand over their weapons. Athens, meanwhile, has promised whatever aid is needed.
--Arsenis's announcements yesterday appeared to fail to convince striking secondary school teachers to return to classrooms.

--According to reports, the US is pressuring Athens to receive armed rebels who refuse to hand over their weapons for fear of reprisals from the Albanian government. The plan, according to the reports, is to allow the rebels safe haven in Greece until the crisis in the neighbouring country is defused.
--Turkey is as European as Greece, Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos says in the US.
--Easter and summer holidays will be late in coming for high school students, in line witht he education ministry's measures to make up for lost lessons.

--Development Minister Vasso Papandreou plans to shake public utilities and organisations (DEKOs) out of their lethargy, beginning with a code of obligations the electricity company, DEH, has before its customers. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
